An SQLite database can be used in an android app for saving structured data
SQLite provides security for data in your applications
You can create a db using the execSQL() method
To create a table in the database you need to first override the onCreate() method within the subclass of SQLiteOpenHelper
To put information into a database you cannot create your own user method
the syntax of an SQLite database is as follows: SQLiteDatabase mydatabase = openOrCreateDatabase("your database name",MODE_PRIVATE,null);
To delete information in the database you do not require a selection criteria that identifies the rows
Content providers act as a layer between the DB and the activity and manage access to a central repository of data

An advantage of a content provider is that it is a good abstraction layer between the data source and the UI code so it can add data validation, manage a structured set of data and modify how the data is stored
A content provider can help in easily sharing data with other apps
A contract is used to interact with the database itself to draw out information
A contract is used to contact the content provider
A content provider knows which app you want to draw information from without specifying
All apps use the same content provider
To access data in your content provider you use a content resolver object
A content resolver resolves the content within an application by providing resulting queries
An app talks to the resolver and calls the appropriate methods to the provider
Content resolvers act like a middle man and determines which provider will handle the URI
In the video, the google+ app draws out information from the contacts app directly through using a content provider
A content resolver uses the same methods of create(), read(), update() and delete() corresponding to the abstract methods of a content provider i.e. query(), insert(), update() and delete()
There is a content resolver for each app
